intro: Gnaphalium uliginosum var. lasiocarpum, commonly known as the woolly sandwort, is a low-growing perennial plant native to moist, sandy or peaty habitats. It belongs to the Asteraceae family and is characterized by its dense, white to greyish fuzzy covering on the stems and leaves. The plant produces small, inconspicuous yellow flowers that are typically clustered in heads. Its leaves are linear to oblanceolate, often with a hairy texture, and it thrives in cool, damp environments. It is often found in bogs, heathlands, and along the edges of wet meadows.
